replies.msg: 對象係英國民眾，並唔係英國政府

有件事都幾值得開心
之前幾次urgent questions佢地都係搵Mark Field頂，都係講廢話遊花園，feel到佢hea答

但Mark Field因為攻擊氣候問題示威者單野 令佢潛哂水
而家英國執政黨幫香港講說話既風向強過以前
實際行動就唔知喇
支持，英國在情在理都要幫啦屌

replies.msg: 解散咗喇

悲情應該冇用
英國精英主義離地同廢老保守民族主義大多數掌權
我覺得應該向住民族主義入手
依家brexit啲廢老俾人煽動晒覺得英國可以好似大英年代噉好威，對世界好有影響力，仲要大鑊到搞到兩大黨死噉滯
我地應該從依啲民粹心態入手
講香港係大英前國土，因為保守黨精英主義親歐親中背棄大英，自我貶低，放棄香港
依家全世界都反中國，大英前領土急要我地出手，英國仲要自貶做縮頭烏龜幾耐？save hong kong, our old friend.
仲要打經濟牌話香港送5000億畀支那做無謂嘢，英國可以駐軍保護嚟換錢拎嚟fund NHS

replies.msg:
我覺得我上面方法真係有用
依家選緊首相
bojo同女婿都開口撐香港，但點先令佢地更加緊張？用選票同黨嘅前途嚟捆綁
依家啲廢老想Brexit，覺得可以令英國係好似大英帝國咁好威，我地就專打依張牌
到廢老都不斷講香港，首相就要跟，尤其依家Brexit party食緊保守黨啲票，如果首相唔跟民意行，一大選就會滅黨
對留歐派都有用，因為佢地冇可能公然為咗鬥脫歐派而舐共唱反調，唔合乎公義，噉同時影響埋左派，仲可能因為噉佢地兩黨要鬥強硬嚟爭票，所以依個方向包贏

replies.msg:
Hong Kong prospered when it was governed by the United Kingdom and was once this great country's inalienable international partner. Since the handover to China in 1997, contrary to what was agreed in the Sino-British Joint Declaration, we have seen the involvement of China and the Hong Kong government in eroding the fundamental values that were introduced by the United Kingdom, including the rule of law and human rights.
We are keen to restore our relationship with the great United Kingdom, this can be by way of trade deal which can support the NHS and other public services. We urge you to stand with us.

可自己作落去。

前英國外海土地公民上

平時一般英國政客唔會理香港呢壇蘇州屎。
但今次唔同，因為英國好可能提早大選。
靠政客自發去提出香港呢個議提再不斷spin落去其實無乜可能，但如果香港呢個議提可以係英國民間炒熱佢就咩政客都會衝入去拎政治利益(例子可以睇下台灣)
第一步棋係G20登報已經做得好靚，英國民眾已經知道呢件事
第二步回歸日衝入立法會𦦙港英旗呢一幕直頭係震撼
第三就係加埋大陸口交部發癲大巴車落侯俊偉到，呢個on9助攻英國根本無得唔正視
但英國政府一定係想大事化小，所以我地唔可以俾佢停，一定要佢繼續spin，等到香港議提變成佢地既大選政綱

[ 海外文宣 ] 點解要衝擊立法會
https://lih.kg/1283180
- 分享自 LIHKG 討論區
要求BNO 平權

代朋友出 post

I am a Hong Konger currently studying at university. I am writing not to raise awareness (that has already been achieved by countless newspapers and reports across the globe), but to plead for support from the British government.

I was born in 1997, the year the British government ended their rule over Hong Kong and handed her over to China. It was twenty-two years ago when the agreement was made to maintain Hong Kong’s status quo for fifty years. Twenty-two years – a blink of eye to some, and yet a lifetime ago to my generation, and to those younger than me. Hong Kong as a Special Administrative Region is what we know, and what we have always known. I grew up in a city that is one of the largest international centres for trade and finance, a city that celebrates both multiculturalism and the distinct local culture. This, unfortunately, is a Hong Kong that is crumbling in our midst today, being eaten away bit by bit by Chinese domination. You have seen the violence on the streets; you have seen the tears of mothers and fathers; you have seen the blood shed by sons and daughters. Now I ask that you stand with us.

History cannot be reversed or altered, what is done is done; the only matter at hand is the preservation of the future. Hong Kong’s autonomy, our freedom of press, our freedom of speech, our very identity, have been upheld by a fragile piece of agreement – that of the ‘one country, two systems’ policy – marked not only by the ink of the Chinese, but also the ink of the British. This piece of paper is now burning, alongside the people who have fought for it. I then urge you, I implore you, not to forsake the promise you made to the people of Hong Kong on the 1st of July twenty two years ago – help us in our fight for justice.

I now end my letter with a quote from Ulysses, by Lord Alfred Tennyson:
We are not now that strength which in old days
Moved earth and heaven, that which we are, we are;
One equal temper of heroic hearts,
Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will
To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.

We strive, we seek, we find.
We shall not yield.
